Expectation1: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation1: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Expectation2: Show love and kindness to others, following the teachings of Jesus
Situation2: They encounter a significant moment where showing love and compassion is essential
Story: I stared at the code review comments piling up in my inbox, each one pointing out the same thing: performance issues in the new feature I’d spent weeks building. My manager’s message was clear—fix it before tomorrow’s release. I felt the pressure mounting, knowing the team was counting on me to deliver clean, efficient code. As I was about to dive back into debugging, I noticed a message from a colleague, Sarah. She sounded upset, asking if I had a moment to talk. I remembered her father was in the hospital, and she’d been struggling lately. As a Christian, I knew I should show compassion, listen, and offer support, just as Jesus taught. But the clock was ticking, and every minute spent away from my code meant risking the team’s trust and the project’s success. My heart ached as I weighed the demands—be the reliable developer my team needed, or be the caring friend my faith called me to be. I sat frozen, torn between two worlds, unsure which to choose.
